Award.AwardTitle: Ninth International Conference on Computational Advances in Bio & Medical Sciences (ICCABS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Computational techniques are drastically impacting the way in which scientific and engineering research are conducted. Impressive advances have been made in different areas including biology, medicine, and drug discovery. Given the great importance of these areas to the society at large, it is essential to advance the state-of-the art in them. Such advances can be made when the scientists from these domains work together and come up with the best possible diagnosis tools, treatment procedures, drugs for various diseases, etc. Even though a number of conferences exist today in the general area of bioinformatics, they focus on one of these three areas to a large extent. The Ninth International IEEE Conference on Computational Advances in Bio and medical Sciences (ICCABS) has the goal of bringing together scientists in biology, medicine, and drug discovery and hence serving as a collaboration platform for them. These collaborations are likely to result in the solution of some of these challenging problems.<br/><br/>The requested funds will be used to support the travel expenses of graduate students. These students will get to meet experts and listen to their research results. Not only will the attending students but so will their colleagues at their home institution, since when attendees return to their schools they will communicate their experiences with other students. The conference proceedings will be of great use to students, researchers, and practitioners. Journal special issues are also planned.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background

Computational techniques are revolutionizing the way in which research is conducted in science and engineering. Unsurpassed advances have been made in various areas. This is particularly true in the domains of biology, medicine, and drug discovery. Given that these areas are of utmost importance to the society at large, it is imperative that every effort is made to enable research advances in them. It is not enough if advances are made in these areas in isolation. These communities have to work together to help each other and come up with the best possible diagnosis tools, treatment procedures, drugs for various diseases. Even though a number of conferences exist today in the general area of bioinformatics, they focus on computational biology to a large extent.

 

A major goal of this project is to conduct a conference to bring together scientists in all the three areas and hence serve as a platform for bridging the research efforts in these areas. The name of the conference is the International Conference on Computational Advances in Bio and medical Sciences (ICCABS). The Ninth ICCABS was held at the Florida International University, Miami, from November 15th to November 17th.

 

Intellectual Merit

The topics of interest to the conference spanned biology, medicine, and drug discovery. Some of the broader topics covered were: Biomedical image processing, Biomedical data and literature mining, Biological Big Data Analytics, Computational genetic epidemiology, Computational metabolomics, Computational proteomics, Databases and ontologies, Data Integration, Gene regulation, Genome analysis, Health Informatics, High-performance bio-computing, Immunoinformatics, Molecular evolution, Population genomics, Sequence analysis, Structural bioinformatics, Systems biology, Transcriptomics, etc. Attendees of the conference have benefited in enhancing their knowledge in these areas.

 

Broader Impacts

The conference was a great success as reported by the attendees. Around 50 persons attended the conference. All the talks were well attended and appreciated. The social events were also a big success. Funds from NSF were used to support 8 graduate students. Out of these, 2 are females (from the University of Southern California and the Clemson University). One of these two students (Shuzhen Kuang) also got the best paper award in the conference. The other students came from University of Delaware, Indiana University, North Carolina State University, Georgia State University (two), and the University of Connecticut. All of these students work in the area of Computational Biology and Bioinformatics for their Ph.D. theses and hence are highly relevant to the conference.

 

Authors of accepted papers submitted full papers. These papers were put together to produce the Proceedings. Each participant was supplied with a copy of the Proceedings in a flash memory stick. These proceedings have been published by Springer as a part of their Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics (I. Mandoiu, T.M. Murali, G. Narasimhan, S. Rajasekaran, P. Skums, A. Zelikovsky, Computational Advances in Bio and Medical Sciences - 9th International Conference, ICCABS 2019, Miami, FL, USA, November 15-17, 2019, Revised Selected Papers, Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics 12029, Springer 2020, ISBN 978-3-030-46164-5).

 

Out of the full papers accepted for presentation in the conference and the workshop presentations, expanded versions of selected papers have been invited for a special issue of the Journal of Computational Biology: I. Mandoiu, T.M. Murali, G. Narasimhan, S. Rajasekaran, P. Skums, and A. Zelikovsky, Special Issue: 9th International Computational Advances in Bio and Medical Sciences (ICCABS 2019), Journal of Computational Biology, Volume 28, Number 2, 2021.
